Authors: Hemenway B.; Jafargholi Z.; Ostrovsky R.; Scafuro A.; Wichs D.
Author full names: Hemenway, Brett (24824291900); Jafargholi, Zahra (56308652300); Ostrovsky, Rafail (7003645345); Scafuro, Alessandra (35520157500); Wichs, Daniel (24336779600)
Title: Adaptively secure garbled circuits from one-way functions
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, United States; Northeastern University, Boston, United States; University of California, Los Angeles, United States; Boston University, Boston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hemenway B., University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, United States; Jafargholi Z., Northeastern University, Boston, United States; Ostrovsky R., University of California, Los Angeles, United States; Scafuro A., Northeastern University, Boston, United States, Boston University, Boston, United States; Wichs D., Northeastern University, Boston, United States
Abstract: A garbling scheme is used to garble a circuit C and an input x in a way that reveals the output C(x) but hides everything else. In many settings, the circuit can be garbled off-line without strict efficiency constraints, but the input must be garbled very efficiently on-line, with much lower complexity than evaluating the circuit. Yao’s garbling scheme [31] has essentially optimal on-line complexity, but only achieves selective security, where the adversary must choose the input x prior to seeing the garbled circuit. It has remained an open problem to achieve adaptive security, where the adversary can choose x after seeing the garbled circuit, while preserving on-line efficiency. In this work, we modify Yao’s scheme in a way that allows us to prove adaptive security under one-way functions. In our main instantiation we achieve on-line complexity only proportional to the width w of the circuit. Alternatively we can also get an instantiation with on-line complexity only proportional to the depth d (and the output size) of the circuit, albeit incurring in a 2O(d) security loss in our reduction. More broadly, we relate the on-line complexity of adaptively secure garbling schemes in our framework to a certain type of pebble complexity of the circuit. As our main tool, of independent interest, we develop a new notion of somewhere equivocal encryption, which allows us to efficiently equivocate on a small subset of the message bits. © International Association for Cryptologic Research 2016.
Author Keywords: Adaptive security; Garbled circuits; Online/offline twoparty computation
Index Keywords: Efficiency; Timing circuits; Adaptive security; Garbled circuits; Line efficiency; Lower complexity; On-line complexity; One-way functions; Strict efficiency; Two-party computation; Cryptography
